body:
Technology and new media are changing how we fight against corruption. We have witnessed an increase of citizens starting to develop tools to promote transparency and inviting others to denounce corruption by sending source documents, videos and stories through a variety of mechanisms.
Building trust: why security matters?

Surveillance cameras, digital fingerprints left all over the Internet, geographic localization, transmission of sensitive data through unencrypted channels, software that monitors a user behavior new technologies increased the opportunities to hold governments, corporations and politicians accountable for their actions. But technologies can be used for different purposes, such as easy, cheap new tools for corrupt governments, parallel powers and unethical corporations to control and surveil activists, public interest groups and citizens. Now they can know exactly who you are, where are you located, where are you reading your emails from, the content you browse, the newspapers you read online, the topics you are interested into, your preferences, your circle of friends and family, including pictures. In fact, any repressor have nowadays more tools than never before to control and react against any activist.

Last July we got worrying news from Ivory Coast. Théophile Kouamouo1, one of Francophone Africa's leading bloggers, and the project leader of the Rising Voices grantee Abidjan Blog Camps was arrested for publishing a newspaper report and refusing to reveal his sources. He was accused of “theft of administrative documents.” Recently, Ali Abdulemam from Bahrein was arrested for “spreading false news” on the Internet2.

Most of the projects we documented lack an essential component: rigorous standards of privacy3, security and anonymity by design. Some of the projects we documented are based in the most violent, repressive and less free environments of the World. In the prelude to a third generation of collaborative transparency, one must not forget that in parallel governments around the World are creating the most effective tools - both legal and technological- to neutralize any efforts that might shift the power in many regions.

And again, just as activists are using a combination of online and offline tools to increase the effectiveness of their efforts, criminal networks and repressive governments can use direct violence in the real world, stopping any transparency effort with death threats directed to those leading such projects.

One of the most vibrant and enthusiastic communities, using new technologies against corruption is based in a country where silence and half truths, repression to any form of dissent and parallel powers threaten the daily life of citizens. In a recently published report by Boing Boing it is explained that in this environment, the system of traditional press coverage has broken down. Reporters are often too intimidated or too exhausted to cover the daily bloodletting. Out of this vacuum have emerged a wave of so-called "Narco Blogs," documenting the widening war in graphic detail, showing photography and video and tells stories from the front lines of the war. Many of them publish whatever people sends to them. It can be material sent by a witness, by any citizen, by a victim, by the criminals themselves, even. But what is worrisome is that their identities are rarely protected. In fact, the average citizen thinks that creating a new email account will protect themselves, by doing so, they believe that they will be “anonymous informants”.

In amateur, spontaneous initiatives, that might be understandable, but in funded, long term, widely spread initiatives, not disclosing the risks and not working in an improved environment of high privacy and security standards, is just inadmissible.  Dubiously people know that when they report a corrupt politician using a nickname, from their personal computer at home, someone can easily track them and get even.

By letting people know that they are sending information and reports from their mobile phones that might be easily intercepted, if not encrypted, by explaining that any authority might find their involvement in a “leak” by tracking all the fingerprints left in the disclosed document and by teaching the project leads that there are mechanisms that might help reduce the damage, the project might improve their respect for users.

Sometimes good intentions are not enough and the fingerprint left on a picture which documented an act of corruption you witnessed may put the life of well intentioned citizens in risk, citizens that had the right to know the real threats.

For any project intending to foster transparency and civic engagement it is important to consider the security and privacy of:

- The Community members that will collaborate with using technology.
The servers where the information is stored
The software used by the initiative4
The security of the Website - Application itself.
The security and privacy of the data transmitted from a mobile phone or other devices to the main Website.

After checking all the aspects listed above, the last and most important step is to assess and improve security protocols of the leaders involved in the initiative, both online and offline. There are many institutions, originally created to protect journalists and human rights activists that can assist you in this matter.
